feed.title: Combined summary - Soft-forks and schnorr signature aggregation

entry.title: Combined summary - Soft-forks and schnorr signature aggregation
entry.summary: Bitcoin developers are exploring the concept of signature aggregation to authorize multiple inputs using a single signature. However, implementing this feature poses several challenges, including the validation of every signature. To address this issue, a new segwit witness version, v2, has been proposed that supports Schnorr signature verification and a "pay to public key (hash?)" witness format enabling direct signatures of the transaction to be aggregatable. Additionally, v2 should support MAST scripts and have a CHECK_AGG_SIG_VERIFY opcode for aggregating signatures.There are discussions about the use of unused opcodes in the software's scripting language and whether they should be reclaimed as RETURN_VALID. The most expedient option is causing a RETURN_VALID at parse time. However, disabled opcodes cause failure at parse time even if they aren't being executed, so there is precedent for this behavior. Developers also discussed the implementation of an opcode for multisig but noted it only works with m-of-n and does not support more complex formulas for how signatures can be combined. As a solution, it may make sense to consider BLS signatures, which have many practical benefits, starting with them being noninteractively aggregatable.Soft-forking in new opcodes can be done by bumping the segwit script version or redefining OP_NOP opcodes as OP_CHECK_foo_VERIFY opcodes. The proposed solutions aim to make aggregate signatures possible while ensuring compatibility with existing Bitcoin infrastructure. However, some developers suggest focusing on Schnorr signatures, Taproot, MAST, and re-enabling opcodes instead of interactive signature aggregation. Aggregate signatures complicate blind signature protocols such as partially-blind swaps and break the assumption that one signature can spend at most one UTXO.In addition, developers discussed other aspects to consider for signature aggregation, such as the consensus-critical aggregation algorithm and whether non-interactive half-sig aggregation can go in at the same time. A detailed explanation of the Bellare-Neven verification algorithm was provided, which requires two communication phases amongst the signers. Core will maintain a config setting allowing users to prevent the hard fork from activating via UASF until the next release after activation.
